item.title: Thought: Links vs. Tags
item.description:
Quick observation while organizing notes today:

Tags = “this note is about X” Links = “this note relates to that specific note”

Tags create broad buckets. Links create specific bridges.

I’ve been over-using tags when I should be linking. A note about [[Spaced Repetition]] doesn’t just need the tag “learning” - it needs a direct link to [[Progressive Summarization]] because they’re related techniques.

The [[Note-Taking|knowledge graph]] shows this clearly: tags create dense clusters, links create meaningful paths between clusters.

item.title: Progressive Summarization
item.description:
Progressive summarization is Tiago Forte’s method for extracting value from notes over time. Instead of processing everything upfront, you distill notes progressively as you use them.

The Layers

Each pass adds a layer of highlighting:

Layer 0: Original content (capture) Layer 1: Bold the most interesting passages Layer 2: Highlight the bolded passages that stand out Layer 3: Write a brief summary at the top Layer 4: Remix into your own original content

item.title: Bidirectional Linking
item.description:
Bidirectional linking means that when note A links to note B, note B automatically knows about and displays the connection back to A. This simple mechanism transforms how we navigate and discover knowledge.

Why Backlinks Matter

Traditional links are one-way streets. You know where you’re going, but you can’t see where you came from. Backlinks complete the picture.

Consider a note about “Machine Learning”. Without backlinks, you only see what ML links to. With backlinks, you discover:

item.title: Evergreen Notes
item.description:
Evergreen notes are notes designed to grow and improve over time. Unlike fleeting captures or project-specific documentation, evergreen notes are investments in your future thinking.

Characteristics

Concept-oriented: Written about ideas, not sources or events. A note titled “Spaced Repetition” is evergreen; “Notes from Chapter 3” is not.

Densely linked: Connected to many other notes, forming a web of knowledge. Each new connection adds context and value.

Written for yourself: In your own words, reflecting your understanding. Not quotes or summaries, but synthesis.

item.title: Getting Started with Zettelkasten
item.description: The Zettelkasten (“slip box” in German) is a note-taking method that transforms how you think and write. Developed by sociologist Niklas Luhmann, who used it to write over 70 books, the system creates a network of interconnected ideas. 01 (sidenote: 01 Luhmann maintained his Zettelkasten on paper index cards. Modern digital tools make the method even more powerful. )

item.title: The Atomic Notes Principle
item.description:
The atomic notes principle states that each note should contain exactly one idea. This constraint forces clarity and enables powerful connections.

Why Atomicity Matters

When a note contains multiple ideas, linking becomes ambiguous. Does a link point to idea A or idea B? By keeping notes atomic, every link has a clear, unambiguous target.

Atomic notes are:

  • Self-contained: Understandable without context
  • Linkable: Can be connected precisely
  • Reusable: Can appear in multiple contexts
  • Evolvable: Can be refined independently

The Test

Ask yourself: “Can I summarize this note in one sentence?” If you need multiple sentences covering different topics, the note should be split.

item.title: How to Take Smart Notes
item.description:
How to Take Smart Notes by SÃ¶nke Ahrens introduces Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten method to a modern audience. Luhmann, a German sociologist, wrote over 70 books and 400 articles using this system.

Key Concepts

The Slip-Box System

Luhmann maintained two slip-boxes:

  1. Bibliographical box: Quick references to sources
  2. Main box: His own ideas and connections

The main box is where the magic happens. Each note is:

  • Written in complete sentences
  • Self-contained and understandable in isolation
  • Connected to existing notes via explicit links

Writing as Thinking

Ahrens argues that writing is not the output of thinking but the medium of thinking. The act of writing forces clarity.
